item.title: Japan’s Princess Mako to Marry after Delay and Controversy
item.dc:creator: Shingo Ito
item.description: After years of controversy, Japan's Princess Mako will marry this month, but she will forego traditional rites and will not take a usual payment given to royal women marrying commoners.

item.title: Record 38 Chinese Jets Enter Taiwan Defense Zone on National Day
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: A record 38 Chinese military jets crossed into Taiwan's defense zone as Beijing marked the founding of the People's Republic of China, Taipei said on Saturday.

item.title: ‘Grotesque’: Konami’s ‘eFootball’ Release Mocked by Fans
item.dc:creator: Andrew Mckirdy
item.description: It was meant to "signal a new era of virtual football", but Konami's "eFootball 2022" appears to have missed the goal, with players mocking its graphics and gameplay.

item.title: Vietnam’s Commercial Hub Back in Business after 3-Month Lockdown
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: Ho Chi Minh City on Friday lifted a stay-at-home order that had kept its nine million residents indoors for three months and devastated business in Vietnam's economic hub.

item.title: Facebook Puts Instagram for Kids on Hold after Pushback
item.dc:creator: Joshua Melvin
item.description: Facebook drew outrage for its now paused plans for an Instagram app for kids aged 12 and under. But 13-year-olds are already welcome on social media with few protections and sometimes tragic effects, experts and parents said.

item.title: Hong Kong Approves Jail Terms for ‘Upskirt’ Shots
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: People who take non-consensual photographs up a woman's skirt face up to five years in jail in Hong Kong under a law passed Thursday aimed at tackling voyeurism.

item.title: Influencers but No Fans as Tokyo Game Show Goes Semi-Virtual
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: The Tokyo Game Show welcomed back influencers and media as it opened Thursday, but fans were only allowed virtual access to the top games confab.

item.title: Kim Yo Jong: North Korean Leader’s Newly Promoted Sister
item.dc:creator: Sunghee Hwang
item.description: Sister, adviser, and now top official: the latest promotion of Kim Yo Jong, sibling to North Korea's leader, solidifies her position in Pyongyang's circles of power, analysts say.

item.title: China Clamps Down on Pop Culture in Bid to ‘Control’ Youth
item.dc:creator: Jing Xuan Teng
item.description: From reality TV to online gaming and even pop fandom, China's leadership has launched a crackdown on youth culture in what experts say is a bid to ramp up "ideological control".

item.title: Manny Pacquiao: Philippine Icon, Boxer… Next President?
item.dc:creator: Allison Jackson
item.description: Manny Pacquiao, who said on Wednesday that he is retiring from boxing at 42, is idolized by many in the Philippines both for his punching power and rise from poverty to the peak of world sport.

item.title: Japan Manga Artist Takao Saito, ‘Golgo 13’ Creator, Dies Aged 84
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: Manga artist Takao Saito, who created the most prolific Japanese comic-book series of all time "Golgo 13", has died aged 84, his publisher said Wednesday.

item.title: Four Refugees Who Sheltered Snowden Find Sanctuary in Canada
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: Four Sri Lankan refugees who hid Edward Snowden in their tiny Hong Kong apartments when he was on the run after exposing NSA spying landed in Canada on Tuesday where they were granted asylum, ending years in limbo.

item.title: Nepal Introduces Third Gender Category in Latest Census
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: Nepal has introduced a third gender category in its census for the first time, a move the Himalayan nation's LGBTQ community hopes will bring them greater rights.

item.title: From Mines to COVID: Cambodia Dogs Train to Sniff out Virus
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: Cambodian anti-landmine authorities are training dogs to sniff out Covid-19, hoping the sharp-nosed canines normally used to detect underground explosives can keep the virus on a tight leash.

item.title: ‘No Future’: Trans Woman Fears Death under Taliban
item.dc:creator: James Edgar
item.description: As an Afghan transgender woman, Radwin has suffered brutal sexual violence on the streets and even rejection by her family.

item.title: China Shows Off New Drones and Jets at Zhuhai Airshow
item.dc:creator: Beiyi Seow
item.description: China on Tuesday showed off its increasingly sophisticated air power including surveillance drones, with an eye on disputed territories from Taiwan to the South China Sea and its rivalry with the United States.

item.title: Hong Kong Man on National Security Trial over Protest Chants
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: A Hong Kong man who chanted protest slogans pleaded not guilty to inciting secession on Tuesday in the second national security case to come to trial as authorities wield the sweeping new law to snuff out dissent.

item.title: Coolant Leak ‘Likely’ Sparked Giant Tesla Battery Fire in Australia
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: A three-day blaze that completely incinerated two giant Tesla batteries at a vast energy storage site in Australia was probably sparked by a coolant leak, safety regulators said Tuesday.

item.title: Afghan Saffron Boss Says Taliban Will Not Silence Her
item.dc:creator: James Edgar
item.description: An Afghan business leader who employs hundreds of women on her saffron fields has vowed to speak up for the rights of her workers, and "not remain silent" under Taliban rule.

item.title: South Korea’s President Moon Raises Dog Meat Ban
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: South Korea's President Moon Jae-in raised banning the eating of dogs in the country on Monday, his office said, a traditional practice that is becoming an international embarrassment.

item.title: Hakuho: The Mongolian Who Shattered Sumo’s Records
item.dc:creator: Mathias Cena
item.description: Mongolia-born Hakuho's retirement from sumo ends a career that saw him shatter just about every record in the storied Japanese sport, which gripped his imagination from childhood.

item.title: ‘Shang-Chi’ Leads N. America Box Office for Fourth Week
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: Disney blockbuster "Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings," featuring Marvel's first leading Asian superhero, dominated the North American box office for its fourth weekend, taking in $13.2 million, industry watcher Exhibitor Relations said Sunday.

item.title: Japan Awaits Wedding News as Royal Sweetheart Returns
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: Japanese romantics and royal-watchers held their breath for a wedding announcement as Princess Mako's boyfriend returned to Tokyo on Monday, following years of public controversy over their marriage.

item.title: TikTok Says It Has over 1 Billion Users
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: TikTok said Monday it now has more than a billion active users, just four years after the hugely popular video-sharing app was launched by Chinese group ByteDance.

item.title: Stars Lend Voices to World-Spanning Concert for Climate, Vaccines
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: A "once-in-a-generation" music event circled the world Saturday, with a slew of megastars taking the stage in New York and beyond for Global Citizen Live -- 24 hours of shows across the planet to raise awareness on climate change, vaccine equality and famine.

item.title: China’s Tutoring Ban Hits Overseas Teachers and Cultural Links
item.dc:creator: Laurie Chen
item.description: Every morning, Sam Josti logged on from her US home to teach children halfway around the world, just one of thousands of foreign language tutors giving Chinese students a rare window into Western culture.

item.title: Kabul’s Carpet and Antique Dealers Struggle after Foreigners Flee
item.dc:creator: James Edgar
item.description: Traders of carpets, antiques and souvenirs on Kabul's famed Chicken Street said Sunday business has completely dried up since the vast majority of foreigners left the Afghan capital as the Taliban took over.

item.title: The Canadians Freed in China’s ‘Hostage Diplomacy’
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: Two Canadians detained in 2018 and accused of spying in China were freed from harsh detention conditions and are heading back home Saturday, bringing an end to a bitter three-year diplomatic row.

item.title: China’s Central Bank Rules All Crypto Transactions Are Illegal
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: China's central bank on Friday said all financial transactions involving cryptocurrencies are illegal, sounding the death knell for the digital trade in China after a crackdown on the volatile currencies.

item.title: Chinese Game Makers Vow to Cut Effeminacy, Limit Underage Players
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: Hundreds of Chinese video game makers have vowed to police their products for "politically harmful" content and enforce curbs on underage players, as the government cracks down on the entertainment industry.

item.title: Surfing Doctor Finds Simple Life-Saving Shark Bite Treatment
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: How do you help someone with their leg bitten off by a shark? Groundbreaking research by an Australian medic-surfer has uncovered a simple way to stop bleeding and save lives.

item.title: Meng Wanzhou: Huawei’s ‘Princess’ on the Rebound
item.dc:creator: Michel Comte
item.description: As the daughter of the founder of Chinese telecoms giant Huawei, Meng Wanzhou was known internally as the "princess" of the company and its possible future leader, but for nearly three years, she's been stuck in Canada fighting extradition to the United States.

item.title: Ex-Head of Chinese Liquor Giant Moutai Jailed for Life for Bribery
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: The former head of Chinese liquor firm Kweichow Moutai, the world's most valuable spirits company, has been jailed for life for taking more than $17 million in bribes.

item.title: Afghan Women Taekwondo Fighters Feel Defeated by Taliban
item.dc:creator: James Edgar
item.description: Zarghunna Noori has always been a fighter, but the 22-year-old taekwondo champion -- who dreamt of representing Afghanistan at the Olympics -- says she has finally met her match.

item.title: Evergrande Founder Calls for Construction, Sales to Resume
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: The head of teetering Chinese developer Evergrande has urged staff to resume construction and sales to deliver properties, state media reported Thursday, as the firm battles to avoid a collapse that could send shockwaves through the world's number two economy.

item.title: Facebook Ordered to Release Anti-Rohingya Posts for Genocide Case
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: A US judge has ordered Facebook to release posts the social network removed over their role in inciting government-backed violence against the Rohingya people in Myanmar.

item.title: Island-Hopping: Genetics Reveal How Humans Settled Remote Pacific
item.dc:creator: Natalie Handel
item.description: Easter Island's famous megaliths have relatives on islands thousands of miles to the north and west -- and so did the people who created them, a study said Wednesday.

item.title: Murakami Library Unveiled at Author’s Alma Mater in Tokyo
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: Haruki Murakami fans can marvel at a vast collection of the Japanese author's novels, scrapbooks and vinyl at a cavernous new library unveiled Wednesday at his old university in Tokyo.

item.title: Sri Lanka Urges Protection of Afghan Buddhist Heritage
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: Sri Lanka called Wednesday on the world to safeguard the Buddhist heritage of Afghanistan under the Taliban, who provoked outrage by destroying giant Buddha statues when they were last in power.

item.title: Bats with COVID-Like Viruses Found in Laos
item.dc:creator: Kelly Macnamara
item.description: Scientists have discovered another clue to the origins of the virus that causes Covid-19, with bats living in caves in Laos found to be carrying a similar pathogen that experts suggest could potentially infect humans directly.

item.title: ‘Joe Ferrari’ Case Lifts Lid on Thai Police Corruption
item.dc:creator: Pathom Sangwongwanich
item.description: A flashy cop with a taste for fast cars falls from grace following the leak of spine-chilling footage of a brutal interrogation gone wrong.

item.title: ‘This Is Our Homeland’: Women Plead for Basic Rights in Afghanistan
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: As the Taliban increasingly excludes women from public life in Afghanistan, some are determined to speak out despite the threat of retribution from the hardline Islamist group.

item.title: Rare Rhino Horns Go up in Flames in India Anti-Poaching Campaign
item.dc:creator: Pranjal Baruah
item.description: Nearly 2,500 rare rhino horns were destroyed Wednesday in the first ceremony of its kind in northeastern India as part of an anti-poaching drive to mark World Rhino Day.

item.title: Evergrande Agrees Deal to Avoid Default on Key Bond
item.dc:creator: Beiyi Seow
item.description: Embattled Chinese property titan Evergrande said Wednesday it had agreed a deal with domestic bondholders that should allow the conglomerate to avoid missing one of its interest payments and avoid default, but its deeper debt burden remains.

item.title: Barbers Suffer under Taliban Rule as Afghans Shun Fashion
item.dc:creator: James Edgar
item.description: Quiffs, mohawks, and crew cuts were hairstyles Nader Shah was accustomed to styling for image-conscious young men in Afghanistan's third-biggest city of Herat.

item.title: Iron Curtain Falls on Hong Kong Cinema as Censors Demand Cuts
item.dc:creator: Su Xinqi
item.description: Once renowned for world-class cinema, Hong Kong's film industry was already struggling before the latest hurdle -- Chinese mainland-style censorship as authorities take their purge of dissent into the cultural sphere.

item.title: Crunch Time for Evergrande, but No ‘Lehman Moment’
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: With the future of Evergrande hanging in the balance, global markets have plunged on fears that one of China's biggest developers could collapse and cause a contagion throughout the world's number two economy and beyond.

item.title: BTS Dance through UN to Promote Youth Solutions for Planet
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: It wasn't exactly the screaming audience BTS is accustomed to but the Korean pop sensations had another sort of world stage Monday as they addressed the United Nations.

item.title: ‘Art Is Dying’: Afghan Artists Hope to Resist Taliban Rule
item.dc:creator: Joris Fiorit
item.description: Two days after the Taliban seized Kabul last month, 26-year-old artist Sara took the terracotta plates she'd painted with images praising inspirational Afghan women -- and hurled them to the ground.

item.title: Duterte Drug War Enforcer Says Prefers to be ‘Hanged’ in the Philippines
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.description: The main architect of Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's drug war said Monday he would rather be "convicted and even hanged" by a Filipino court than a foreign one for his role in the deadly crackdown.
